cluster_relations.rel_desc: The gravitational pull of a black hole is strong enough to prevent light from escaping.
cluster_relations.subject_entity_name: gravitational pull of a black hole
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Black Hole Event Horizon Light Trapping

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: within or near the event horizon of the black hole

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The black holeâ€™s gravitational pull prevents anything from escaping once past the event horizon.
cluster_relations.subject_entity_name: gravitational pull of a black hole

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: for any time after crossing the horizon
qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: applies to all matter and light (implied)
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Effect: prevents escape from black hole

cluster_relations.rel_desc: At the Schwarzschild radius, the escape velocity is equal to the speed of light.
The Schwarzschild radius marks where the gravitational pull becomes strong enough to prevent escape.
cluster_relations.object_entity_name: gravitational pull of a black hole

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: escape velocity reaches speed of light

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject exerts an influence or constraint that prevents the object (or entities associated with it) from escaping a region or potential well.
args.justification: Both relations describe the black hole's gravitational pull acting as a constraint that prevents escape (of light or matter) once within/beyond a certain region; they share the same core predicate semantics of preventing escape.
These relations express that a physical influence (gravity) constrains the ability of entities to escape a region, fitting a class of relations about escape-preventing constraints.
The gravitational pull causally leads to the impossibility of escape; this is best modeled as a causal constraint between cause (gravity) and effect (no escape).

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two physical quantities have equal numerical value or magnitude under the stated conditions.
args.justification: The relation states that the escape velocity at the Schwarzschild radius is equal to the speed of light; this is a numerical equivalence between two quantities, not merely a loose similarity.
This relation expresses strict equality between two physical quantities, which fits a class of quantitative equivalence relations.
Numerical equality between two quantities is a form of identity in value, so this belongs in a broad identity/equivalence group rather than causality or composition.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject specifies or marks the threshold or boundary at which a particular physical effect or condition (described by the object) becomes operative or qualitatively changes.
args.justification: The Schwarzschild radius is described as the point where the gravitational pull becomes strong enough to prevent escape, i.e., it defines the threshold at which this effect holds; the predicate captures the idea of a boundary/threshold condition for a phenomenon.
This relation links a critical radius to the onset of a specific dynamical condition (escape impossible), which is characteristic of threshold or critical-condition relations.
The Schwarzschild radius causally delimits where the physical behavior changes (from possible to impossible escape), making this a causal/conditional boundary relation.
